column23:
La Fundación Empresarial Eurochile fue una iniciativa pionera de la Comisión Europea y el Estado de Chile. Eurochile comenzó a funcionar oficialmente el 12 de marzo de 1993. 
La fundación sirve de puente entre Chile y los países miembros de la Unión Europea; un puente por el que transitan iniciativas empresariales, colaboraciones tecnológicas e intercambios de experiencias beneficiosas para ambas partes. Este concepto de mutuo beneficio es  el que hoy se está imponiendo en la relación entre  la Unión Europea y América Latina. 
Para cumplir con su rol de conexión, Eurochile ha desarrollado múltiples plataformas,  ha facilitado decenas de acuerdos de cooperación, y ha accedido a programas y redes europeas y latinoamericanas de gran alcance. Se han aprovechado al máximo las oportunidades de diálogo y de colaboración con empresarios, autoridades locales e instituciones europeas. Y para ello se han trabajado las cuatro líneas de acción principales en las que Eurochile ha contribuido a través de sus proyectos:  
 
1.- Promoción de negocios desde y hacia Europa para comunicar a las empresas las oportunidades y herramientas que permitan generar negocios con Europa y viceversa para incrementar y facilitar la concreción de vínculos comerciales.  
 
2.- Innovación conjunta chileno-europea para apoyar a las pymes en innovar sus productos, servicios, procesos y modelos de negocios. En este sentido, Eurochile se ha convertido en un puente para la venida de especialistas europeos, capaces de transferir conocimientos y convertirlos en innovaciones en nuestro país sobre todo en los rubros de alimentos, turismo y manejo de energías.  
 
3.- Generación de polos de desarrollo territorial para generar distintos tipos de asociatividad empresarial, acuerdos colaborativos público-privados y encadenamientos productivos locales, regionales, nacionales e internacionales de las pymes chilenas y europeas. Todo esto a través de la transferencia de conocimientos de expertos nacionales e internacionales, participación en ferias, ruedas de negocios, encuentros empresariales e institucionales, seminarios, pasantías y redes. Esto ha contribuido a reducir las desigualdades entre pymes y grandes empresas, a mejorar la productividad, la innovación y la competitividad de las pymes para que avancen en su proceso de internacionalización. 
 
4.- Apoyo a las relaciones institucionales entre Chile, Latinoamérica y la UE para mantener y desarrollar colaboraciones y dialogo institucional con organismos e instituciones de interés.
column25:
La Fundación Empresarial Eurochile es miembro activo de las principales redes de colaboración internacional europeas: 
  
Red Enterprise Europe: Red especializada en apoyar a pequeñas empresas para aumentar su competitividad. Cuenta con 4.000 expertos en 600 instituciones afiliadas en más de 50 países. Chile –representado por Eurochile– Brasil y México son los únicos miembros latinoamericanos, y prontamente se sumarán Argentina, Colombia y otros. La red constituye una herramienta confiable y efectiva, que ofrece oportunidades de negocios, de transferencia de tecnología, e información de primera mano sobre legislación y programas europeos, abriendo múltiples oportunidades para innovar y desarrollar nuevos negocios. Fusionó las antiguas redes de Euro Infocentros y de Centros de Enlace para la Innovación. 
  
European Business Organizations: La Red de Organizaciones Empresariales Europeas es una red creada por la Comisión Europea para fomentar el desarrollo empresarial en los países no comunitarios; conocer la realidad de cada región y difundir información sobre políticas europeas. Cuenta con solo 30 miembros en el mundo, dos de ellos en Latinoamérica: Brasil y Chile, a través de Eurochile. 
  
Programa europeo Horizonte 2020: Dio la continuidad al Séptimo Programa Marco, 7PM. Es una iniciativa de la Comisión Europea que se dedica a financiar la investigación y el desarrollo tecnológico en Europa. Eurochile constituye el Punto Nacional de Contacto para pequeñas y medianas empresas. 
  
TCI Network: Red mundial para competitividad, clústeres e innovación. A través de sus actividades, TCI alcanza a 9.000 profesionales de las agencias de desarrollo, departamentos gubernamentales, polos de competitividad, instituciones académicas, empresas y organizaciones multilaterales de más de 110 países. 
  
Red Nanofutures: Plataforma de innovación y nanotecnología de la Comisión Europea, que se inscribe en el programa Horizonte 2020. Eurochile es el único Punto de Contacto en Chile, complementando sus tareas como socio en el proyecto “Implementación de nanociencia, nanotecnologías, materiales y nuevas tecnologías de producción en los países de América Latina”. 
  
Friends of Europe: Think tank con sede en Bruselas, enfocado en la discusión y pensamiento de los temas políticos, económicos, sociales y medioambientales que enfrentan Europa y el mundo. 
  
Fundación Euroamérica: Organización sin fines de lucro, plural e independiente, que sirve al interés general, cuyo objetivo principal es estimular la cooperación y el entendimiento entre instituciones, empresas y personalidades europeas e iberoamericanas para fomentar, desde el sector principalmente privado, las relaciones entre Europa y América.
column26:
Desde su creación, Eurochile ha realizado diversas actividades orientadas al fortalecimiento de vínculos comerciales entre las empresas chilenas y europeas, a la transferencia de tecnología y saber hacer y al fortalecimiento de la institucionalidad pública con la finalidad de mejorar el entorno de las pymes chilenas.  
  
 
Las siguientes cifras resumen los resultados de los logros de Eurochile:  
 
3.743 pymes chilenas participan de 216 ruedas de negocios/tecnológicas  
 
•24.142 pymes beneficiadas de 251 proyectos de capacitación 
 
•320 expertos europeos traídos a Chile 
 
•4.320 pymes beneficiadas de 96 proyectos de apoyo al mejoramiento productivo utilizando expertise europea 
 
•247 iniciativas de transferencia tecnológica

column9: Bug House Ham Lane Orton Waterville
column23:
Buglife’s aim is to stop the extinction of invertebrate species and to achieve sustainable populations of invertebrates. 
 
We will accomplish our aim by protecting, improving and expanding their habitats (homes) and strengthening the respect given to bug species.  We will achieve this by:- 
 
•    Mobilising, inspiring, enabling and persuading others to take action, through the development and dissemination of knowledge and values. 
•    Undertaking practical conservation projects. 
•    Promoting the value of invertebrates and raising awareness about the challenges to their survival. 
•    Shaping the development of relevant legislation and policy.
column25:
Environment 
Nature 
Pesticide Regulation 
Farming 
Fisheries 
Biodiversity 
Habitats Directive 
Invasive Species
column26:
1.    Improved management of key habitats, including preventing loss and restoring and creating habitat, to enable the recovery of bug populations and to stop further local and national extinctions. 
 
2.    Fewer key invertebrate species in decline; no preventable extinction of native species, or of globally significant populations of introduced species, in any of the UK countries  
 
3.    Increased acknowledgement amongst decision makers and the public (particularly children):- 
•    of the wonder, beauty and importance of bugs and their requirements 
•    of the big issues affecting bugs and the action required to achieve positive change 
•    that individuals and society should take responsibility for resolving threats to bugs 
 
4.    Improved quantity, quality and availability of science, data and evidence directly relevant to bug conservation, including long term monitoring. 
 
Themes 
We will embed across our work two themes addressing urgent, topical issues that impact directly on people: 
 
Theme A) Tackling the Pollination Crisis 
 
Theme B) Securing Healthy Freshwater

column23:
The European Food Information Council (EUFIC) is a non-profit organisation, established in 1995, that responds to the need for accurate and understandable information on food and health. 
 
EUFIC's mission: To offer accessible, appealing and actionable science-based information on food and heath to inspire and empower. 
 
EUFIC's vision: A world where people choose to live healthily because they know how to.  
 
Information that EUFIC publishes has been subject to a review process by members of its Scientific Advisory Board (SAB, http://www.eufic.org/article/en/page/ONEUFIC/rid/eufic-scientific-advisory-board/). The SAB comprises a group of renowned experts from across Europe who advise EUFIC on its information and communication programmes, ensuring that all information is based on scientific evidence, relevance and is factually correct. EUFIC consults with other scientific experts for specific projects in areas such as consumer research and science communication. Given the broad range of subjects addressed in EUFIC’s popular newsletter, Food Today, a dedicated Editorial Board (http://www.eufic.org/article/en/page/ONEUFIC/rid/eufic-editorial-board/) for this publication provides additional insights and feedback. 
 
With its main offices located in Brussels (Belgium), EUFIC collaborates with international, European and national organisations to enhance the impact and outreach of its communication instruments and programmes in other countries. 
 
EUFIC actively participates in European Commission funded research projects (European Commission Directorates General for Research & Innovation), where it contributes as research and dissemination partner. EUFIC is also a member of the EU platform for action on diet, physical activity and health (DG Health and Food Safety).
column25:
As EUFIC communicates science-based information on food and health related topics and is involved in EU-funded research projects, EU initiatives (activities, programmes, projects) and policies that fall under the remits of DG SANTE, DG AGRI, DG JRC, DG RTD, EFSA, etc., are of relevance. 
 
The reason why EUFIC follows those initiatives and policies or legislation is to communicate about them to a wider audience. For example, EUFIC consults legislation when communicating about certain topics like: 
1) food packaging (http://www.eufic.org/article/en/page/FTARCHIVE/artid/food_packaging_unwrapped/) 
2) shelf-life and its importance to consumers (http://www.eufic.org/article/en/page/FTARCHIVE/artid/Food_shelf_life_and_its_importance_for_consumers/)  
3) nutrition and health claims when new legislation was introduced (http://www.eufic.org/en/healthy-living/article/consumer-perception-of-nutrition-and-health-claims)
column26:
EVENTS AND ACTIVITIES  
In 2017 EUFIC participated in the following events/activities, which may be considered as covered by the Register: 
•    Member of the Stakeholder Advisory Board of the Joint Programming Initiative (JPI) Healthy Diet for a Healthy Life (http://healthydietforhealthylife.eu/) 
•    Member of the Scientific Working Group Food and Consumer of the European Technology Platform (ETP) Food for Life (http://etp.fooddrinkeurope.eu/) 
•    Participation in a workshop on CAP and food-related issues, DG AGRI/DG SANTE (invited presentation on consumer behaviour change, Brussels, 31 May) 
•    Participation in the regional symposium of sustainable food systems, FAO/WHO (invited presentation on nutrition leadership, Budapest, 4-5 Dec)

column36:
EUFIC is supported by companies along the food chain – from seed producers, through ingredient suppliers to food manufacturers. EUFIC also receives project funding from the European Commission. EUFIC is governed by a Board of Directors, which is elected from member companies.  
 
Current EUFIC members are: Abbott Nutrition, Bunge, Cargill, Cereal Partners, Coca-Cola, Dow Seeds, DSM, Ferrero, General Mills, Mondelēz Europe, Mars, Nestlé, PepsiCo, Pinar Et, Tereos, Ülker, Unilever.  
All members subscribe to EUFIC's principles and Code of Conduct (http://www.eufic.org/en/who-we-are/funding-governance; http://www.eufic.org/images/uploads/files/EUFIC_Code_of_conduct.pdf).

Djurens Rätt arbetar genom opinionsbildning, politiskt påverkansarbete och konsumentarbete för en värld där djur respekteras som individer med rätt till sina egna liv.

column23:
The Alliance of Lithuanian consumer organisations, established in 2012, unites ten consumer associations. Those associations are: Lithuanian Consumer Association, Lithuanian Consumer Union, Consumer Rights Protection Centre, Lithuanian Association of Bank Customers, the Lithuanian Citizens Advice Union, National Association of Financial Services Consumers, Association “For honesty in banking”, Mažeikiai Consumer Association, Consumer Rigths Institute and Consumer Dispute Arbitrage. 
The main goal of the Alliance is to represent the interest of Lithuanian consumer association’s interests in governmental institutions, business structures and non-governmental sector on the national and international level.
column25:
In order to achieve its goals the alliance works in these main areas: 
Participates in the preparation of legal acts related with consumer protection and makes proposals how to improve the consumer rights’ protection system. Members of the alliance participate in various governmental workshops for example in the State Consumer Rights Protection Authority, in the Council of consumer rights protection (advisory institution of Lithuanian Republic Ministry of Justice) in the Central Bank of the Republic of Lithuania; Tripartite Council of the Republic of Lithuania (institution acting on the equal partnership basis and consisting of representatives from the Government of the Republic of Lithuania, trade unions and employers organisations solving social, economic and labor problems and in such way seeking to maintain social peace and order in the society), Consumer Rights  Supervision Committee discussing relevant consumer issues. 
Cooperates with non-governmental organisations, business associations and universities. 
Seeks to create an alternative dispute resolution framework and to participate in EU alternative dispute resolutions in activities of the association. 
Members of the Alliance actively conducts research, training, and organizes conferences and seminars; 
Represent Alliance members and Lithuanian consumers’ interests in governmental institutions, courts, non-governmental organisations also in international organisations and other institutions. 
Members of the Alliance represent consumer interests in EU institutions, for example in the European Consumer Consultative Group or in the Payment Systems Market Expert Group. 
Spreads information about consumer associations work on the national and EU level. 
The Alliance represents Lithuania in The European Consumer Organisation (BEUC).

column4: Non-governmental organisations, platforms and networks and similar
column23:
Polskie Stowarzyszenie Badań Wspólnoty Europejskiej, będąc organizacją pozarządową, dąży do zapewnienia i popularyzacji rzetelnej i obiektywnej wiedzy na temat europejskich procesów integracyjnych, ze szczególnym uwzględnieniem w nich miejsca i roli Polski. Jednym z celów Stowarzyszenia jest tworzenie fundamentów dla aktywności demokratycznej społeczeństwa europejskiego na wielu poziomach. W wymiarze działań kierowanych do obywateli Stowarzyszenie przyczynia się do poprawy świadomości obywatelskiej w Polsce przez prowadzenie analiz i badań na temat aktualnych procesów integracyjnych w Unii Europejskiej w wymiarze inter- i multidyscyplinarnym.  
Główne cele statutowe Stowarzyszenia obejmują: 
• promocję badań oraz nauczania z zakresu problematyki Unii Europejskiej, 
• analizę strategicznych aspektów funkcjonowania Unii Europejskiej oraz jej polityk, 
• rozwój współpracy i integracji między polskimi naukowcami i badaczami, uniwersytetami i instytucjami, zajmującymi się tą problematyką, 
• promocję powiązań polskich badaczy z badaczami z innych państw UE, członkami sieci ECSA oraz instytucjami UE. 
Ponadto, celem prowadzonych przez Stowarzyszenie działań dydaktycznych i badawczych jest definiowanie odpowiedzi na wyzwania, jakie stoją przed Unią Europejską, jej państwami członkowskimi oraz obywatelami, w zmieniających się uwarunkowaniach regionalnych i globalnych. 
 
PECSA wyróżnia się inter- i wielodyscyplinarnym profilem naukowo-badawczym jej członków. Podejmowane przez nią działania i realizowane projekty z zakresu problematyki europejskiej integrują wiedzę z obszarów kształcenia nauk społeczno-ekonomicznych i nauk humanistycznych, w tym m.in. ekonomii, polityki i stosunków międzynarodowych, prawa i administracji, socjologii i antropologii. 
PECSA należy do międzynarodowej sieci European Community Studies Association – ECSA, która została powołana przez Komisję Europejską w celu promowania integracji europejskiej jako kierunku nauczania. W związku z przyjęciem Strategii Europa 2020 ECSA we współpracy z Komisją Europejską oraz profesorami Jean Monnet podejmuje działania na rzecz opracowania jak najlepszego systemu edukacji w obszarze integracji europejskiej w zmieniającym się otoczeniu międzynarodowym.
column25:
PECSA i jej członkowie interesują szeroko rozumianą problematyką nauki, badań, szkolnictwa wyższego, edukacji, rozwoju społeczno-gospodarczego i innowacji. 
PECSA systematycznie śledzi m.in. aktualności dotyczące Programu Erasmus+ i Horyzont 2020 z uwagi na swój profil działalności.
column26:
PECSA realizuje liczne projekty krajowe i międzynarodowe dotyczące problematyki integracji europejskiej i Unii Europejskiej w ujęciu interdyscyplinarnym. PECSA prowadzi aktywnie działania informacyjno-promocyjne przy wykorzystaniu m.in.: 
1. strony www stowarzyszenia, pecsa.edu.pl 
2. stron www powiązanych, np. conference-euinteg2015.pecsa.edu.pl (strona projektu PECSA) 
3. kont na Facebooku: https://www.facebook.com/stowarzyszeniepecsa/, https://www.facebook.com/euinteg/ 
4. konta na Twitterze, https://twitter.com/pecsa_eu 
5. mailingu do członków i partnerów PECSA 
6. kanałów komunikacji partnerów, np. uczelni wyższych (SGH, UG, UW, UE w Poznaniu, UE w Katowicach)  
7. kanałów komunikacji ECSA-World, itd.

column5: European Association of Airport and Seaport Police (EAASP)
column23:
To prevent and detect terrorist and criminal activity 
affecting the international transportation of 
passengers and cargo 
• To study and recommend methods and uniform 
practices for establishing safeguards against loss 
of property in transit 
• To encourage and develop the exchange 
of information and experience among Law 
Enforcement Agencies countering criminal 
activities at airports and seaports 
• To encourage cooperation between elements 
of the international trade community for the 
development of improved security measures for international cargo 
• To become a more inclusive and integrated body within Europe whilst seeking to develop 
a strategic platform from whence the Association can be increasingly influential over the 
Security and Transport policies affecting Europe.
column25:
From the research perspective, EAASP is on the Advisory Board of two on-going projects: 
 
- Framework Programme 7 - CONSORTIS – (Concealed Object Stand-Off Real-Time Imaging for Security)

column25:
Consumer affairs at EU level is the main topic followed by MDC.  
In particular, on the 2nd of August 2017 MDC has participated in the Public consultation on the targeted revision of EU consumer law directives. 
On the 2nd of February 2016, MDC has participated in the survey about the empowering the national competition authorities to be more effective enforcers.  
On the 15th of February 2016, MDC has also presented to the EU Commission a legal opinion on regarding the notification received by the EU Commission on the proposed merger between the two Italian telephone operators H3G S.p.A. ("H3G") and WIND Telecommunications S.p.A ("WIND").
column26:
MDC main European projects: 
-Market Watch (2014 - 2017):co-funded by the Intelligent Energy Europe Programme of the European Union. Sixteen civil society organisations from all across Europe have come together to form MarketWatch, campaign of testing everyday products in shops and online, MarketWatch will shine a spotlight on those manufacturers and retailers failing to follow EU regulations and depriving their customers of the energy savings they think they are getting. 
- EcoLife (2013 - 2016) -Ecological Lifestyles for CO2 Reductions- is an European Union funded project that aims inform and to give suggestions to European citizens on possible sustainable changes in their daily lifestyles to reduce CO2 and greenhouse effects and global warming. 
- Safer Internet Center – Generazioni Connesse (2012-2014): co-funded by the EU’s Directorate for Communications Networks, Content & Technology. Its aim is to develop awareness raising material, organize campaigns and information sessions for children and young people, parents, carers, social workers and teachers to enable children and young people to make responsible use of on-line technologies. The project is managed by the Instruction Minister, Save the Children and Telefono Azzurro, while MDC acts as implementing partner. 
- Adicae (2009) : co-funded by the EU’s Directorate-General for Justice. It consisted on a European cycle of seminaries for the means of payment fraud prevention in collaboration with the Police and Judicial authorities consumers association and professional organizations. The purpose of the project was the prevention on fraud in means of payment, emphisizing to its transnational dimension and the assistance the victims of these crimes. 
- Periscope (2007-2010): co-funded by the EU's Executive Agency for Health and Consumers for the prevention of child obesity. Periscope as Pilot European Regional Interventions for Smart Childhood Obesity Prevention in Early Age aimed at challenging the increase of child obesity in 3 European countries: Italy, Denmark and Poland.

Mission: To reverse the alarming rise in chronic diseases by providing leadership and policy recommendations based on contemporary evidence. 
 
Objectives: 
- Provide policy recommendations based on contemporary evidence 
- Raise awareness and advocate by engaging with policy-makers 
- Promote the development and implementation of a EU Framework on Chronic Disease 
- Develop and publish position/policy papers 
 
Priorities: 
- Primary and secondary prevention related to chronic diseases 
- Common risk factors - tobacco use, poor nutrition, physical inactivity, alcohol consumption and environmental factors

column23:
The ocean is an interconnected global ecosystem supporting a wide range of uses. Maintaining a healthy ocean requires responsible stewardship by all users. 
The ocean supports a growing range and level of commercial use and other activities. Concerns about the impacts of economic activity on ocean health from increasing use are on the rise. These concerns may limit industry access to marine areas and resources. Ocean users, including those who simply rely on shipping to move goods, are increasingly being held accountable by governments and NGOs for the state of the ocean. Continued ocean access and use will increasingly require the social license to operate - above and beyond simple regulatory compliance - and participation in Sustainable Development Goals. 
Many companies are working to reduce their marine ecosystem footprint. However, the best efforts by a single company or an entire sector will not be enough to address the cumulative impacts on the inter-connected marine ecosystem from growing use across the sectors. Companies dependent on the ocean can achieve business value from working with others in the ocean business community to address shared challenges regarding sustainable development, science and stewardship.  
The World Ocean Council is the only international, cross-sectoral industry leadership alliance on “Corporate Ocean Responsibility”. 
The WOC brings together the diverse ocean business community (shipping, fisheries, oil & gas, aquaculture, offshore renewables, tourism, seabed mining, marine technology, manufacturers, law, retailers, insurers, finance, etc.) to achieve the business benefits of cross-sectoral leadership and collaboration. The WOC is developing global ‘platforms’ on important cross-cutting ocean business and sustainability challenges, e.g. ocean policy & governance, marine planning, invasive species, marine debris, marine sound, marine mammal impacts, water pollution, data collection by industry vessels & platforms, sea level rise/extreme event impacts on ports, priority regions (e.g. Arctic, Indian Ocean), and investment & innovation for ocean sustainable development. 
Responsible ocean companies are invited join the growing number distinguishing themselves as leaders in “Corporate Ocean Responsibility” through the WOC. 
The WOC is the only international, multi-industry alliance for private sector leadership and collaboration in ocean sustainable development, science and stewardship. 
In addition to the 75+ WOC Members from the diverse ocean business community, the WOC Network includes 35,000+ ocean industry and media stakeholders around the world. The WOC is recognized or accredited by numerous U.N. agencies and other international organizations as the credible, global leadership body on ocean business and sustainability.
column25: The World Ocean Council has been following closely the development and/or implementation of the EU Horizon 2020 program

column23:
The Animal Welfare Foundation (AWF) is based in Germany and is an independent, non-profit, and international animal welfare organisation. The Board of Directors as well as the personnel have been engaged in animal protection for many years, only educated and trained personnel works at the organization. In order to gain credibility, no project is carried out without previous validation and the review of the existing scientific and empirical evidence and we do not publish information without evidence. We look for sustainable, long- term solutions to improve the living conditions for farm animals.  
Our work is based on the following ethical principles: 1) Animals are sentient beings; 2) The rights and dignity of the animals are inviolable 3) There is no distinction between animal species 4) There is no moral justification for suffering. The goal of animal welfare is to raise the status of animals, not reduce the status of human vision.
column25: Our main projects are: Farm animal transport within Europe and to third countries, Horsemeat imports, Blood farms and Police training to support the enforcement of Regulation 1/2005 regarding the welfare of animals during transport.

column23:
Cittadinanzattiva onlus (www.cittadinanzattiva.it) è un movimento di partecipazione civica che opera in Italia e all’estero per la promozione e la tutela dei diritti dei cittadini e dei consumatori.  
 
Dal 2000 siamo membri del Cncu-Consiglio nazionale consumatori e utenti presso il Ministero dello Svilupo economico italiano. 
Cittadinanzattiva, che nasce in Italia nel 1978, è presente in Italia con 21 sedi regionali e circa 270 assemblee locali. 
La missione di Cittadinanzattiva trova il suo fondamento nell'art.118 della Costituzione, che recita: "Stato, regioni, province, città metropolitane, comuni favoriscono l'autonoma iniziativa dei cittadini, singoli e associati, per lo svolgimento di attività di interesse generale, sulla base del principio della sussidiarietà". 
Cittadinanzattiva ha come obiettivi: 
•    intervenire a difesa del cittadino, prevenendo ingiustizie e sofferenze inutili 
•    attivare le coscienze e modificare i comportamenti 
•    attuare i diritti riconosciuti dalle leggi e favorire il riconoscimento di nuovi diritti 
•    fornire ai cittadini strumenti per tutelarsi e dialogare ad un livello più consapevole con le istituzioni 
•    costruire alleanze e collaborazioni indispensabili per risolvere i conflitti e promuovere i diritti. 
Cittadinanzattiva si occupa di: 
•    sanità, con il Tribunale per i diritti del malato ed il Coordinamento nazionale delle Associazioni dei malati cronici 
•    politiche dei consumatori, con i Procuratori dei cittadini 
•    giustizia, con Giustizia per i diritti 
•    scuola, con la Scuola di cittadinanza attiva 
•    cittadinanza europa, con Active citizenship network 
•    attivismo civico, in Italia e nel mondo
column25:
Our organization promoted in May 2015 the MEPs Interest Group "Patients’ Rights & Cross-Border Healthcare" with the endorsement of more than 80 civic and patient organizations across Europe.  
Moreover, we advocated their request to recognize officially the value of citizens’ initiatives, such as the European Charter of Patients’ Rights  and the European Patients’ Rights Day. This request has been included also in the “Report on safer healthcare in Europe: improving patient safety and fighting antimicrobial resistance (2014/2207(INI))", approved unanimously on April 2015 by the ENVI Committee first, and then in plenary by the European Parliament in May 2015.

Our Aims and Objectives as ITUC-Africa are : 
 
 Strives for full productive and decent employment, elimination of discrimination based on race, sex, nationality or creed 
 Fights for improvement of working and living conditions, introduction, maintenance and extension of social security for all and raising workers living standards. 
 Maintains and develops strong, independent, democratic, powerful and effective international, national, sub-regional, regional, continental organizations of free trade unions. 
    Seeks the universal recognition and application of trade union rights. 
    Furthers the establishment, maintenance and development of trade union organizations. 
    Strengthens international trade union solidarity giving assistance to oppression, repression victims and other sufferers due to natural and industrial disasters 
 Coordinates defence of free trade unions against any campaign destroying rights through infiltration and subjugation of labour organizations by totalitarian or other anti labour forces. 
 Assists war and subjugation victims through speedy rebuilding of economies. 
 Develops resources of countries to promote economic, social and cultural progress.

column5: European Regions Research and Innovation Network (ERRIN)
column23:
ERRIN is a Brussels-based platform of  Research and Innovation Organisations and Stakeholders in Regions. ERRIN  aims to strengthen regional Research and Innovation capacities by exchanging information, sharing best practice, supporting European project development, policy shaping and profile raising by working together with a partnership approach. ERRIN helps regions get their voice heard in Brussels. 
  
Through its 14 Working Groups, ERRIN facilitates contacts between regional offices and regions so that they can enhance their knowledge of European policy in Research and Innovation and develop strategic European projects to strengthen regional competitiveness. 
  
ERRIN plays a key role in Brussels by raising the profile of its members and the regional agenda in EU policies in order to make them respond better to the needs of European regions. ERRIN also works closely with European Institutions and other relevant Networks and Organisations to advance the interests of regions in R&I.

column23: Acting as an intermediary between its members - the European business community in Vietnam - and local, national, regional and European authorities, EuroCham Vietnam lobby on its members' behalf, advocate improvements in the business environment, raise awareness on key issues and disseminate information on doing business in Vietnam and the region.
column25: EuroCham is a consortium member of the EU-Vietnam Business Network (EVBN) and a sub-contractor of the South-East Asia IPR SME Helpdesk which are the initiative of the European Commission.
column26:
Projects: EuroCham is a consortium member of the EU-Vietnam Business Network (EVBN) and a sub-contractor of the South-East Asia IPR SME Helpdesk which are the initiative of the European Commission. 
 
Events: EuroCham Vietnam regularly organises advocacy events, public-private dialogues and networking events. EuroCham Vietnam also actively cooperates with its partners in cross-promoting events. 
 
Publications: EuroCham Vietnam publishes its annual Whitebook which provides a concise view of the issues affecting European businesses in Vietnam, putting forward specific recommendations to help improve the current situation or resolve relevant challenges. EuroCham also publishes other publications such as EVFTA Reports, Greenbook.

column23:
International Co-operative Alliance-Africa Region is one of the regional offices of the ICA. It serves, unites and represents ICA member organizations in Africa. ICA Africa 
Region promotes and strengthens autonomous and viable co-operatives throughout the region by 
 
• serving as a forum for exchange of experience and a source of information 
on co-operative development, research and statistics 
• providing technical assistance for co-operative development 
• collaborating with national governments, United Nations organizations and African regional organizations. 
• The Alliance Africa Region will strive to promote and strengthen the co-operative movement in the region and provide services to co-operatives with the following objectives: 
• promoting the co-operative movement in Africa 
• promoting and protecting co-operative values and principles 
• facilitating development of economic and other mutually beneficial relations between its member organizations 
• promoting sustainable human development and further the economic and social progress of people, thereby contributing to peace and security in Africa 
promoting equality between men and women in all decision making and activities within the co-operative movement 
• lobbying for an enabling environment for co-operative development in Africa. 
 
It has 35 members from 22 countries

column5: European Bureau for Conservation and Development (EBCD)
column23:
Founded in 1989, EBCD is an international environmental non-governmental-organization (NGO), based in Brussels, with the main objective to promote the conservation and sustainable use of natural renewable resources both in Europe and worldwide. Its statue embraces the principles set out in the World Conservation Strategy (IUCN, UNEP, WWF, 1981), Agenda 21 and the Rio Declaration. 
 
It supports science-based solutions, full stakeholder participation, due consideration for the socio-economic aspects and for cultural diversity. 
 
EBCD aims at: 
  Achieving a balance between the need to conserve nature and the need for economic growth. 
  Ensuring that conservation/ management decisions are based on the best available scientific advice. 
  Ensuring that any utilisation of natural resources is sustainable, both biologically and socially. 
  Ensuring full stakeholder participation in decision making process. 
  Raising awareness of the principles and problem solving methods for sustainable production, use and consumption. 
 
In the International arena, EBCD follows closely environmental agreements and conventions such as CBD, CITES, UNFCCC etc. Working in full collaboration with the European institutions, EBCD monitors EU developments on environmental policy with the main focus on marine and fisheries issues and it provides advice to policy makers and stakeholders. 
 
Having worked with the European Parliament for over 25 years, EBCD provides the Secretariat of the European Parliament Intergroup “Climate Change, Biodiversity and Sustainable Development”. This Intergroup, being the biggest and the most active in the EP, constitutes a cross-party, cross-committee and cross-sectoral platform for Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) to learn, discuss and create policies geared towards finding solutions to issues related to sustainable development with main focus on climate change and biodiversity. 
 
Besides the Intergroup, EBCD organises high level seminars and workshops. Mainly focused on marine and fisheries issues, they bring together all the players seeking to find balanced solutions. 
 
As an active member of International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) since its establishment, EBCD works closely with its network of experts, Commissions and Programmes as well as with other organisations and institutions actively involved in the conservation of biodiversity and sustainable management of natural renewable resources. EBCD also provides the Secretariat to the Fisheries Expert Group of the IUCN - Commission of Ecosystem Management.

column5: Fonds Mondial pour la Nature France (WWF France)
column23:
Depuis 1973, le WWF France mène des actions concrètes pour sauvegarder les milieux naturels et leurs espèces, assurer la promotion des modes de vie durables, influencer les décideurs et accompagner les entreprises dans la réduction de leur empreinte écologique.  
 
Le WWF France agit au niveau national et au niveau européen (en coordination avec le bureau européen du WWF -European Policy Office / EPO- du WWF et les autres bureaux du WWF situés en Europe) ainsi qu’au niveau international (au travers de projets transfrontaliers, de l’influence dans des conférences internationales ou de financement de projets situés hors du territoire français).

column5: Stowarzyszenie Lokalna Grupa Działania "Dolina Raby" (LGD Dolina Raby)
column23:
Stowarzyszenie jest Lokalną Grupą Działania (LGD)zgodnie z art. 34 ROZPORZĄDZENIA PARLAMENTU EUROPEJSKIEGO I RADY (UE) NR 1303/2013. LGD działa na obszarze sześciu gmin: Biskupice, Gdów, Łapanów, Nowy Wiśnicz, Trzciana i Żegocina. Celem działalności jest zrównoważony rozwój społeczności tych gmin. 
Zadaniem LGD jest opracowanie i realizacja Lokalnej Strategii Rozwoju. Różni partnerzy - podmioty prawne i osoby fizyczne składają wnioski o dofinansowanie projektów ze środków europejskich. Obecnie jest to Europejski Fundusz Rolny na rzecz Rozwoju Obszarów Wiejskich. Stowarzyszenie stara się też pozyskiwać środki na realizacje innych projektów. Obecnie realizujemy projekty z Programu Erasmus+  i projekty ze środków regionalnych władz samorządowych.

1)    Implementation of the Strategic Guidelines for the Sustainable development of European Aquaculture

column5: Alianza Cooperativa Internacional para las Americas (ACI-Americas)
column9: De la Iglesia de Loreto 300 norte 100 oeste
column23:
Misión: ACI-Américas es la organización de la Alianza Cooperativa Internacional que, siendo coherente con su identidad, vela por los valores y principios cooperativos, integra, representa y promueve el cooperativismo como modelo de construcción de sostenibilidad económica, social y ambiental. 
Los objetivos específicos son: a) Ser un líder reconocido en la construcción de la sostenibilidad económica, social y ambiental; b) Ser el modelo más relevante para resolver las necesidades de la gente y c) Ser el modelo empresarial que garantiza una mayor equidad, transparencia y justicia social.
column25: Son de interés los marcos jurídicos que regulan las cooperativas así como las políticas públicas que de una u otra forma afectan al sector cooperativo.  Iniciativas y proyectos relacionados con Desarrollo Sostenible,  políticas y metodología sobre incidencia política.
column26: Seminarios, talleres y conferencias para crear un ambiente favorable al desarrollo de las cooperativas, trabajando en colaboración con otros actores de la sociedad civil organizada. Se editan publicaciones mensualmente y trimestralmente como medios de comunicación además del sitio web, Facebook y twitter.

column23: Στόχοι του ΕΙΥ είναι η διεξαγωγή και υποστήριξη της επιστημονικής έρευνας με αντικείμενο την προαγωγή της υγείας και την πρόληψη ασθενειών, με επίκεντρο τον Ελληνικό πληθυσμό. Για να εκπληρώσει την αποστολή του, το ΕΙΥ συνεργάζεται με Ελληνικά και διεθνή ιδρύματα, οργανισμούς και ιδιώτες, για την τεκμηρίωση και διάδοση αξιόπιστων γνώσεων για την υγεία.
column25:
Μέσω των αποτελεσμάτων των ερευνητικών προγραμμάτων και των πληθυσμιακών μελετών για την υγεία και την διατροφή,  το Ελληνικό Ίδρυμα Υγείας συμβάλει στη διαμόρφωση πολιτικής υγείας και διατροφής στην Ελλάδα. Tο Ελληνικό Ίδρυμα Υγείας συμμετέχει:  
 
σε προγράμματα της Ευρωπαϊκής Αρχής για την Ασφάλεια των Τροφίμων, "European Food Safety Authority" (http://www.efsa.europa.eu), 
 
σε δράσεις του διακυβερνητικού οργανισμού "European Cooperation in Science and Techonolgy" (http://www.cost.eu), ο οποίος αποτελεί το μακροβιότερο ευρωπαϊκό πλαίσιο στήριξης της διεθνής συνεργασίας μεταξύ των ερευνητών και των επιστημόνων σε όλη την Ευρώπη. 
 
στο Ευρωπαικό Δίκτυο Δράσης του Παγκόσμιου Οργανισμού Υγείας για τον περιορισμό της πίεσης που ασκείται στα παιδιά από την προώθηση (marketing) των ανθυγιεινών τροφίμων και ποτών, "European Action Network on reducing marketing pressure on children" (http://www.euro.who.int/en/health-topics/disease-prevention/nutrition/policy/member-states-action-networks/reducing-marketing-pressure-on-children) 
 
στο Ευρωπαϊκό Δίκτυο Δράσης για το Αλάτι του Παγκόσμιου Οργανισμού Υγείας, "European Salt Action Network" (http://www.euro.who.int/en/health-topics/disease-prevention/nutrition/policy/member-states-action-networks/reducing-salt-intake-in-the-population)
column26:
Το Ελληνικό Ίδρυμα Υγείας συμμετείχε ή συμμετέχει στα εξής έργα ενδεικτικά: 
 
στο ερευνητικό πρόγραμμα "Ευρωπαϊκή πρωτοβουλία για την προώθηση της παρακολούθησης των συγκεντρώσεων βιολογικών δεικτών σε Ευρωπαϊκούς πληθυσμούς" (http://www.hhf-greece.gr/hbm4eu_gr.html) 
 
στο έργο "Υποστήριξη συλλογής δεδομένων εθνικών διατροφικών ερευνών σε άτομα ηλικίας 10 έως 74 ετών, σύμφωνα με τις συστάσεις της Ευρωπαϊκής Αρχής για την Ασφάλεια των Τροφίμων - European Food Safety Authority" (http://www.hhf-greece.gr/efsa2015_gr.html), 
 
στην μεγαλύτερη και μεθοδολογικά αρτιότερη διατροφική επιδημιολογική έρευνα που έχει πραγματοποιηθεί μέχρι σήμερα στην Ευρώπη. Πρόκειται για το "Ευρωπαϊκό Πρόγραμμα συνεργασίας Ιατρικής και Κοινωνίας", ΕΠΙΚ (http://epic.iarc.fr),  
 
στο ερευνητικό πρόγραμμα με τίτλο "Πρόγραμμα και στοχευμένη δράση για την διατροφή και την υγεία του ελληνικού πληθυσμού: ανάπτυξη και εφαρμογή μεθοδολογίας και αποτύπωση" (http://www.hydria-nhns.gr/index.html), 
 
στο "Ευρωπαϊκό Δίκτυο για την προώθηση της έρευνας στα καροτενοειδή και των εφαρμογών της σε σχέση με τα αγροτικά προϊόντα και την υγεία"(http://www.hhf-greece.gr/eurocaroten_gr.html), 
 
στο ευρωπαϊκό πρόγραμμα "Ανθρωποκεντρική προσέγγιση βασιζόμενη σε πίστωση αναγνωριστικών μονάδων (credits) για την υιοθέτηση υγιεινών επιλογών διαβίωσης και ισορροπημένης Μεσογειακής διατροφής στο πλαίσιο κοινωνικής συμμετοχής και καινοτομίας για την προαγωγή της υγείας" (http://www.credits4health.gr/index.php).

column23:
European Movement Ireland is an independent, not-for-profit, membership-based organisation working to develop the connection between Ireland and Europe. Founded in 1954, European Movement Ireland is the oldest Irish organisation dealing with the EU, pre-dating Ireland’s membership of the Union in 1973 by almost twenty years. 
 
Our aims are to provide an independent, reasoned, non-governmental voice on European issues; to increase awareness and understanding of European issues among all sectors of Irish people; to disseminate factual information about Europe in language that is clear and understandable; to encourage Irish engagement at European level; and to act as a conduit between Ireland and Europe, representing and articulating Irish opinions to our EU counterparts. 
 
Our vision is for European issues to be discussed in Ireland in a reasoned, robust and fair manner. 
 
Our values include engagement - we work to foster proactive engagement on European issues through innovative, dynamic and creative participation; responsibility - we work to ensure we all take responsibility for the role we play in EU matters and for how we as a people, and as a country, actively engage with Europe; accountability - we work to increase accountability and transparency at both European and Irish levels.
column25: EM Ireland follows the breath of EU initiatives, policies and legislative files, with a distinct focus on those which have a particular impact on Ireland and those related to the areas of Future of Europe, youth, education, graduate jobs, Erasmus+ and language.

column35:
Finn Church Aid is a founding member of the ACT Alliance, a coalition of operators of church development work, humanitarian aid, and advocacy. It is one of the largest charity organisations in the world and includes over 140 operators in 100 different countries. http://actalliance.org/ 
 
In addition FCA is a member of ACT Alliance EU, which is a joint association of European church aid organisations. http://actalliance.eu/ 
 
As a member of ACT Alliance EU, FCA is also part of the CONCORD, which is the European confederation of Relief and Development NGOs. https://concordeurope.org/ 
 
FCA is also a member of VOICE (Voluntary Organisations in Cooperation in Emergencies), a network of European organisations providing humanitarian aid. http://www.ngovoice.org/ 
 
The Lutheran World Federation (LWF) is the largest programme implementation partner of Finn Church Aid. In 2015 FCA facilitated the long-term development programmes of the LWF in eight different countries, and the organisation is also a significant partner of FCA in humanitarian aid. Together with LWF we advocate for human rights and inter-religious dialogue at the UN level. https://www.lutheranworld.org/ 
 
Through the World Council of Churches FCA supports 
programmes that promote peace and facilitate equality and support human rights. http://www.oikoumene.org/en/ 
 
FCA is a member of CHS Alliance, and has been certified 
against the Core Humanitarian Standard on 
Quality and Accountability. https://corehumanitarianstandard.org/ 
 
Furthermore, FCA is a member of Finnwatch, an organisation studying and monitoring Finnish companies operating in developing countries. http://www.finnwatch.org/en/

column23:
Founded in 2004, APDES - Agência Piaget para o Desenvolvimento – is a non-profit NGDO (Non-governmental Development Organisation) that promotes the integrated development. 
 
APDES main goal is to intervene with vulnerable communities and people, in order to improve their access to healthcare services, employment and education, working for the empowerment of institutions and individuals, as well as for the reinforcement of social cohesion. The organisational profile of APDES comprehends four lines of intervention that guide the developed projects: health, harm reduction and human rights; health education; social cohesion and employment; cooperation and development. 
 
All the tasks carried out follow successfully delineated work principles, such as research, participative methodologies, outreach intervention, advocacy, assessment and interdisciplinary approach. 
 
Headquartered in Vila Nova de Gaia, APDES develops several activities in this municipality and cities like Porto, Barcelos, Guarda, Viseu, Setúbal and Lisbon. Since 2008, APDES has internationalised its scope of action and organised several initiatives in European countries, Cape Verde and Angola – a territory where the process of institutional formalisation of the Agency is currently being carried out, alongside intervention and training projects. 
 
The affiliation of APDES with other organisations is quite extensive; APDES is the founding and constituent member of several national and international networks in the ambit of harm reduction associated with psychoactive drugs use, sex work, access to employment and human rights.  
 
In 2011, after being recognised as a Non-governmental Development Organisation (NGDO) by the Camões I.P., APDES started to benefit from the status of public utility. 
 
Our goal is to decrease the risks associated with drug use and sexual activity; the possible negative consequences of these behaviours (at an individual or communitarian level) can be reduced through adequate interventions. Additionally, we focus on the research of more effective ways to protect our beneficiaries – sex workers, people who use drugs and others who are in a vulnerable social situation – as well as the communities they live in. Our main concern is to promote health and defend the human rights of those we work with, through projects designed with their active involvement - in order to guarantee the well-being and health of the participants.

column5: Apimondia - International Federation of Beekeepers' Associations (Apimondia)
column23:
Apimondia exists to promote scientific, technical, ecological, social and economic apicultural development in all countries and the cooperation of beekeepers’ associations, scientific bodies and individuals involved in apiculture worldwide. 
 
It also aims to put into practice every initiative that can contribute to improving apicultural practice and to rendering the obtained products profitable.
column25: Apimondia is a partner in the three-year EU project "BPRACTICES" aimed at promoting good beekeeping practices particularly on the health dimension, assess their economic impact, devise a technology application for traceability of bee products and disseminating the relevant outcomes. Date of project inception February 2017
column26:
In addition to the above-mentioned EU project, Apimondia has also launched a worldwide initiative for licensing bee genetic resources to prevent commercial exploitation of same. 
 
Apimondia is also involved in the proclamation of the World Bee Day within the United Nations' system, with expected endorsement by the UN General Assembly in December 2017. 
 
Apimondia is also looking into producing a flagship publication on beekeeping to act as a reference document for the sector that is scheduled for possible release at the next Apimondia international congress in 2019

column5: Stichting Advisory Council for pelagic stocks (Pelagic AC / PELAC)
column23: The Pelagic AC prepares and provides advice on the management of pelagic fish stocks on behalf of the fisheries sector and other stakeholders. It covers the pelagic stocks of all the areas, excluding the stocks in the Baltic Sea and Mediterranean Sea. The Pelagic AC (as a foundation under Dutch law) was inaugurated on 16 August 2005, and consists of a General Assembly, an Executive Committee and two Working Groups. The work is furthermore done in collaboration with observers, for example, from non-EU countries that have an interest in particular stocks or regions covered by the Pelagic AC.

column23:
Offering inspiration and support (consultancy, training) for the development and realisation of an, in the long term, regenerative society, by using (amongst others) biomimicry thinking as a methodology. 
 
BiomimicryNL is the biomimicry expert in the Netherlands and uses the knowledge and genius of nature to work on future proof concepts and organizations. We believe in the potential of biomimicry, and work on iconic projects to prove this potential. The goal is to use the genius of nature in R&D and innovation processes to accelerate the transition to circulair thinking  
 
It's our main goal to create impact with biomimicry, and also work to new concepts and organizations using the Biomimicry methodology. We mostly work with parties in the Netherlands, but because of our relationship with Biomimicry3.8 and Biomimicry Institute, we are able to help with any biomimicry challenges and all over the world.  
 
Our activities:  
- Reach out - lectures, presentations, exhibitions, communication on biomimicry with the goal to create awareness on biomimicry as an upcoming scientific field, sustainability strategy and innovation method.  
- Biomimicry trainings and workshops, online and 'in person' for students and professionals 
- Development of education material for K-12 up till University/PostDoc level WO  
- Biomimicry consultancy for governments and business

column20: CEO of founding member Dogs Trust
column23:
The EU Dog & Cat Alliance was created in 2014. Our members are organisations from across the EU, including veterinary organisations, organisations which are involved in the rescue/rehoming of dogs and cats and organisations which are working to protect dog and/or cat welfare. The Alliance’s main focus is on improving EU legislation in relation to dogs and cats. 
 
We aim to: 
 
- Lobby the European Union to introduce and improve EU legislation in relation to dogs and cats, and engage in other EU activities. 
 
- Engage with other key EU stakeholders and collaborate wherever possible to improve the welfare of dogs and cats in the EU. 
 
- Provide a forum for the sharing of information on dog and cat welfare issues between our members. 
 
- Gather evidence on the dog and cat issues we work on and produce reports and briefings to support our position. 
 
The EU Dog & Cat Alliance works on issues which are of priority to dogs and cats in the EU.

column5: Organisation for Respect and Care of Animals (ORCA)
column25: ORCA implements activities directed toward supporting Serbia's EU integration process (focusing on negotiation chapters related to agriculture and rural development – Chapter 11; food safety, veterinary and fitosanitary policy - Chapter 12; fisheries – Chapter 13 and environment and climate change – Chapter 27). ORCA is a member of the EU Platform on Animal Welfare, an expert group tasked to assist the European Commission with the development and exchange of coordinated actions on animal welfare. ORCA has been selected by DG SANTE as only CSO from the Western Balkan region. ORCA is committed to the improvement of policies, legislation and practice related to animal welfare, environmental protection in Serbia, through various activities such as analysis, creating proposals to change the laws and regulations, creation of policy documents, and advocating for the adoption of such proposals (e.g. Animal Welfare Law, Nature Protection Law, Veterinary Law, National Sustainable Development Strategy, etc.). Currently, in the frame of the EU funded regional project, we are coordinating development of a regional policy on sustainable agriculture.

ORCA is a member of EU Platform on Animal Welfare, and expert body of the European Commission.  
 
In addition we are members of several international networks:  
- Eurogroup for Animals,  
- Species Survival Network,  
- CEEWeb for Biodiversity  
- EUROBATS (member of advisory board).  
 
ORCA is also a member of important national networks and bodies such as:  
- National Convention on the European Union (NCEU)  
- Sectorial Civic Society Organizations (SCSO) 
Both NCEU and SCSO are platforms for consultations between national authorities and civil sector in relation to EU intergration process 
- Network Natura 2000, Resource Centre of Serbia,  
- Council for the Improvement of Food Production Sector,  
- National Ethical Council for the Welfare of Animals used in Research and local ethical committees at faculties and scientific institutions in Serbia (University of Belgrade - Faculties of Medicine, Biology, Agriculture and Pharmacy; Institute for the Application of Nuclear Energy – INEP, Military Medical Academy, Institute of Virology, Vaccines and Sera “Torlak”).

column5: Foundation for a Drug Free Europe (FDFE)
column23: The purpose of FDFE, established in 2004, is preventing and stopping debilitating drug use by educating youth and non-users concerning the harmful effects that drugs can inflict upon the body, mind and personality. The Foundation has also the aims to create and put into action drug prevention projects with governments and institutions, elaborate cycles of conferences, round tables and to focus around the different aspects of the drug abuse in Europe and help create drug free European societies by collaborating with like-minded groups and organisations sharing the same purpose.
column25:
EU Drug Strategy and Action Plan 
- 
And interest in the decisions of the UNODC - Vienna and of the OSCE activities  
- 
Outcome Document of the UNGASS 2016
column26:
Since four years the FDFE is organizing  in Brussels an Annual European Meeting on Drugs and Prevention open to the civil society, 
 
All the associations in Europe and members of FDFE are celebrating the UN International Day Against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking (26 June), 
 
There are also specific national or local events such as: 
-the Yearly Drug Free Marathon in Hungary (2000 Kms),  
-the annual Czech Republic Cyclo-run across the country (1500 Kms), 
-distribution of 300 000 informative booklets for the UEFA Champions League (an annual continental club football competition organised by the Union of European Football Associations - UEFA) in the French cities participating, 
-the Summer Anti-Drug Marathon in Kazan (6 weeks -Russia) 
 
Beside this: 
 
-at grass-roots level, regular distributions by the associations, in the main European cities, of educative booklets in the streets or to the shopkeepers; 
 
-organisation of conferences and video projections of our materials, to schools, youth associations and institutions; 
 
-In 2018 we did a drug prevention training to a Unit of the Spanish Army; 
 
-Two side Events were organized: 
 
On 13 March at the UNODC (Vienna) during the 61th CND session on:  
.Law Enforcement and Sustainable Drug Use Prevention, 
with a Commandant of the Spanish Army, a Police Officer from Italy and a Director of Drug demand Reduction for the High Intensity Drug Trafficking Areas of California. 
 
On 26 June in Geneva, Palais des Nations during the 38th Human Rights Council on: 
.Human Rights for Children and Drug Prevention, 
with the participation of the Spanish Army, the Southeast European Law Enforcement Center and a Deputy of the Grand Conseil of Geneva.

column5: Sveriges Konsumenter, The Swedish Consumers' Association (-)
column23:
Sveriges Konsumenter är en obunden, demokratiskt förankrad, ideell organisation som står på din sida. Vi kämpar för alla konsumenters självklara rätt till skydd, inflytande och möjlighet att göra medvetna och hållbara val.  
 
Vi vill göra det lättare för dig och alla andra att handla säkert och hållbart – och svårare för företag att sälja skadliga produkter eller lura folk. Via lobbying och påverkan ökar vi konsumenternas makt och skydd i samhället och verkar för en ekonomiskt, ekologiskt och socialt hållbar konsumtion.  
 
Våra största frågor är mat, hälsa, miljö, banker och integritet på nätet. Vi har 24 medlemsorganisationer och arbetar både nationellt, på europeisk nivå och internationellt.
column25: Sveriges Konsumenter följer och lobbar i konsumentfrågor och i synnerhet frågor som berör konsumentens skydd och rättigheter. Vi har särskilt fokus på hållbar utveckling, livsmedel, finansiella tjänster, digitala rättigheter, hållbara textilier.
column26:
Sveriges Konsument äger konsumenttidningen Råd&Rön med en upplaga på 60 000. 
 
Sveriges Konsumenter bedriver konsumentvägledning på uppdrag av Svenska kommuner i huvudsak i Stockholmsregionen. 
 
Sveriges Konsumenter bedriver följande projekt: 
Fair Finance guide - om hållbara finansiella tjänster 
Stilmedveten - om hållbar textilkonsumtion 
Med rätt att handla - om kognitivt tillgänglig konsumtionsmiljö 
Standardiseringsprojektet - för främjande av deltagande i standardisering 
Consumers Ask Reach - projekt om kemikalier i konsumentprodukter

column5: MINHA TERRA - Federação Portuguesa de Associações de Desenvolvimento Local (MINHA TERRA)
column6: Entidade de interesse público, de direito privado, sem fins lucrativos
column23:
A MINHA TERRA – Federação Portuguesa de Associações de Desenvolvimento Local (ADL), constituída em Fevereiro de 2000, por iniciativa de um grupo de ADL responsáveis pela gestão da Iniciativa LEADER, reúne as entidades gestoras do LEADER / DLBC Rural com objetivos de representação, formação, informação, comunicação e conceção e implementação de soluções e intervenções em prol do desenvolvimento integrado dos territórios rurais. Com competências a nível da organização e implementação de programas e iniciativas de alcance local, regional, nacional e transnacional, a Federação "tem como área de intervenção todo o território nacional". 
As 58 ADL federadas na MINHA TERRA representam, no seu conjunto, mais de 93% do território nacional e as suas capacidades de iniciativa e concretização dizem diretamente respeito a mais de 4 milhões de portugueses, habitantes em zonas rurais. 
Nas últimas duas décadas a MINHA TERRA tem contribuído para as dinâmicas nos territórios rurais e promoção da sua sustentabilidade, conduzindo iniciativas duráveis com efeito multiplicador na economia e competitividade locais e regionais. Este movimento, fortemente impulsionado pelas ADL e assente na definição e implementação de estratégias, processos e parcerias de base territorial, tem contribuindo decisivamente para minimizar os impactos, e nalguns casos inverter o agravamento, de um cenário de “crise profunda no mundo rural português”, de que o isolamento, o êxodo e envelhecimento das populações, os problemas ambientais e de ordenamento territorial são uma clara expressão. Os projetos implementados pelas ADL permitem dar resposta a necessidades específicas dos espaços rurais, minorando efeitos de debilidades estruturais e potenciando um desenvolvimento integrado e sustentável, alicerçado no empreendedorismo endógeno.
column25:
A Minha Terra foi parceira formal para Portugal da segunda e terceira edição da campanha Parlamento Rural Europeu, cujos encontros finais decorreram respectivamente em Sharding na Áustria em 2015 e Venhorst, na Holanda, em Outubro de 2017. Cada um dos eventos reuniu cerca de 250 participantes oriundos de muitos países europeus. No momento em que as instituições europeias estão a decidir o futuro dos programas e dos fundos da UE, o Parlamento Rural Europeu pede uma nova base unificada para o financiamento do desenvolvimento local.  
A Minha Terra acompanha as actividades da Rede Europeia de Desenvolvimento Rural, e de outras organizações, em particular as destinadas à Abordagem LEADER e Desenvolvimento Local de Base Comunitária (CLLD). Em 2017, destaca-se a participação no Seminário transnacional dedicado à temática «Alcançar resultados através do DLBC: pôr o método em ação», que decorreu na Suécia, em 2016. 
Participação no Seminário “Capitalizar experiências do DLBC – Construir comunidades locais resilientes”, com intervenção no painel final sobre o futuro do DLBC, em representação da ELARD – European LEADER Association for Rural Developement, realizado em Gyor, na Hungria, numa organização da DG REGIO e DG EMPL da Comissão 
A Minha Terra foi responsável por uma intervenção key-note com o tema “From LEADER to Community-Led Local Development: A critical perspective on European rural policies” na Conferência "New rural geographies in Europe: actors, processes, policies", em Braunschweig. 
Enquanto vice-presidente da rede ELARD, a Minha Terra assumiu um papel ativo na conferência «Renovar o DLBC/LEADER para 2020+ – Celebrar 25 anos de LEADER na Europa!» nos dias 22 e 23 de novembro, na Estónia. As recomendações da cnferência foram integradas numa declaração «Renovar o LEADER/DLBC para 2020+» a submeter à Comissão Europeia, outras instituições europeias e autoridades de gestão dos Estados-membros a partir de janeiro de 2017. 
A Minha Terra assume a presidência da ELARD para 2018-2019, numa eleição realizada em novembro de 2017, em Laulasmaa, na Estónia, através da eleição de Maria João Botelho, presidente da Federação Minha Terra. 
A nível europeu a Minha Terra atua como representante dos GAL portugueses nas estruturas de governação da Rede Europeia de Desenvolvimento Rural, nomeadamente na Assembleia das Redes Rurais e no Subgrupo “Leader and Community–Led Local Development”. 
(http://ec.europa.eu/transparency/regexpert/index.cfm?do=groupDetail.groupDetail&groupID=3277&NewSearch=1&NewSearch=1) 
Regularmente a Minha Terra efetua análise aos pareceres do Comité das Regiões, Regulamentos Comunitários, Relatórios Técnicos do Tribunal de Contas Europeu e demais documentação produzida, principalmente pela Comissão Europeia, nomeadamente, através da Rede Europeia de Desenvolvimento Rural.
column26:
Em 2012, no âmbito das comemorações dos 50 anos da Política Agrícola Comum a MINHA TERRA concorreu aos Prémios de Comunicação da PAC com o “Jornal Pessoas e Lugares” e os Programas de Rádio “Terra Viva”, produzidos em parceria com a TSF no último trimestre de 2011, com apoio do Programa da Rede Rural Nacional. Ambos os projetos foram classificados como boa prática pelo júri. Na sessão de encerramento Campanha 50 anos da PAC, os Programas de Rádio foram eleitos o segundo melhor projeto na categoria “Comunicação com o Público”. 
Em 2016, a MINHA TERRA representou Portugal na 14ª Semana Europeia das Regiões e Cidades (Open Days), onde a ELARD foi responsável pelo workshop “DLBC – Como funciona?”. Sob o tema “Regiões e cidades para o crescimento sustentável e inclusivo”. O Workshop organizado em torno das experiências sueca, portuguesa e checa do DLBC, teve como tema central a simplificação dos Fundos Europeus Estruturais e de Investimento (FEEI). 
Participação no seminário sobre Cooperação LEADER/DLBC em Dijon, organizado pela LEADER France – Federação Francesa dos GAL, que decorreu a 30-09-2016, onde membros da MINHA TERRA apresentaram a ELARD e um retrato do LEADER/DLBC na Europa. 
Intervenção sobre o DLBC em Portugal no debate “Comunidades como agentes de mudança: o desenvolvimento local na UE no pós-2020” promovido, em Outubro de 2017, em Bruxelas, pela Rede de Desenvolvimento Local (LDnet), em parceria com a ELARD, no âmbito da Semana Europeia das Regiões e das Cidades (EWRC 2017).

column35:
A nível internacional: 
. ELARD: organização que agrupa cerca mais 2000 Grupos de Ação Local (GAL) de vários países da UE, proporcionando um fórum de reflexão, debate e cooperação entre organizações da sociedade civil interessadas nos grandes desafios que se colocam à Europa Rural. A Minha Terra assumiu a vice-presidência da ELARD desde Fevereiro de 2016 até ao final de 2017. Em 2108 e 2019, assumirá a presidência. 
. Assembleia das Redes Rurais (no âmbito da Rede Europeia de Desenvolvimento Rural), que interliga as partes interessadas no desenvolvimento rural em toda a União Europeia (UE), contribuindo para a execução eficaz dos programas de desenvolvimento rural (PDR) dos Estados-Membros, gerando e partilhando conhecimentos, bem como facilitando o intercâmbio de informações e a cooperação no espaço rural europeu. A Federação integra a Assembleia, assim como o Subgrupo LEADER, em representação dos GAL Portugueses 
. Em 2017 a Minha Terra participou no Parlamento Rural Europeu 2017, como interlocutor do processo em Portugal, a convite da Comissão Organizadora, uma parceria de três redes rurais pan-Europeias, a European Rural Community Alliance (ERCA), a PREPARE - Partnership for Rural Europe e a European LEADER Association for Rural Development (ELARD) de que a Federação é associada 
 
A nível nacional: 
.Conselho Económico e Social, órgão consultivo da Assembleia da República, em representação das Organizações da Agricultura Familiar e do Mundo Rural e tem participado nos trabalhos do Plenário do CES e da CEPES, assim como em diversos grupos de trabalho 
.Rede Rural Nacional, estrutura de ligação entre agentes com papel ativo no desenvolvimento rural, que querem partilhar as suas experiências e conhecimentos, melhorar o desempenho e obter melhores resultados. Tem como objetivos: promover a participação e o trabalho conjunto entre os agentes de desenvolvimento rural; transferir as boas práticas e novos conhecimentos para qualificar a intervenção dos agentes de desenvolvimento rural; melhorar a conceção e aplicação das medidas de política de desenvolvimento rural; promover a imagem e o potencial dos territórios rurais 
.Conselhos Regionais das Comissões de Coordenação e Desenvolvimento Regional, onde têm assento os mais representativos agentes do desenvolvimento sustentável ao nível local e regional têm como objetivo acompanhar as atividades das CCDR, a execução dos programas operacionais de financiamento comunitário, pronunciar-se sobre os projetos de relevância e dar parecer sobre os planos e programas de desenvolvimento regional, nomeadamente sobre a aplicação de investimentos da administração central na região 
. Comissão Nacional de Coordenação do Combate à Desertificação, tem como funções garantir a coordenação e o acompanhamento da execução do Programa de Ação Nacional de Combate à Desertificação e promover a articulação e integração do mesmo nos objetivos e nos procedimentos associados à Convenção das Nações Unidas de Combate à Desertificação. A Comissão para além de organismos públicos integra organizações da sociedade civil 
.Bolsa Nacional de Terras, instrumento criado pelo Ministério da Agricultura e gerido pela DGADR para facilitar o acesso e a utilização das terras. No âmbito desta iniciativa, a Federação lidera uma parceria integrando 35 ADL reconhecidas como entidades Gestoras Operacionais da Bolsa de Terras. A Federação integra o Grupo de Acompanhamento da Bolsa de Terras, que tem como objetivo partilhar informação sobre o ponto de situação do funcionamento da Bolsa de Terras, e apresentação da proposta da estratégia de dinamização e de divulgação 
.Comissões de Acompanhamento do PDR2020, do PRORURAL+ e dos Programas Operacionais Regionais 
.Conselho de Acompanhamento da Revisão da Política Agrícola Comum (PAC), que tem como missão identificar os principais desafios e contribuir
column36:
A Minha Terra congrega hoje todas as entidades reconhecidas como Grupos de Ação Local (GAL) rurais no Continente e nas Regiões Autónomas - 58 entidades, responsáveis por 60 GAL, que representam no seu conjunto mais de 93% do território nacional e cujas suas capacidades de iniciativa e de concretização dizem directamente respeito a mais de 5 milhões de portugueses, residentes nas zonas rurais. A representatividade das ADL federadas – traduzida na diversidade e natureza dos seus associados presentes no conjunto das parcerias locais – contam mais de 3.500 entidades, entre pessoas coletivas de direito público e privado e pessoas individuais. 
 
Link: http://www.minhaterra.pt/associados.T4.php

column23:
The Changing Markets Foundation partners with NGOs on market focused campaigns. 
 
Our mission is to expose irresponsible corporate practices and drive change towards a more sustainable economy. 
 
Our approach is based on two key ideas: 
 
-sustainability is an urgent challenge to which most solutions already exist; 
-market forces can be leveraged to drive rapid and self-reinforcing change towards a more sustainable economy. 
 
Changing Markets was formed to accelerate this transition.
column25: The Changing Markets Foundation campaigns on a range of topics including climate change, environmental protection and pollution prevention, food and health, and resource efficiency and circular economy.
column26: The Changing Markets Foundation conducts research, including market and supply-chain investigations, to help advance the campaigns that we support. To see examples of our work, please visit http://changingmarkets.org/campaigns/

column23: The mission of IVSA is to benefit the animals and people of the world by harnessing the potential and dedication of veterinary students by promoting the international application of veterinary skills, education and knowledge. The way in which this is achieved, is by arranging annual meetings (congresses and symposia), running permanent projects, facilitating exchanges and publishing newsletters. IVSA has several international committees and working groups that work on the permanent projects, but also on new activities regarding one health, animal welfare, veterinary education and mental wellness in the veterinary profession.
column25: The policy areas in which IVSA operates are: Animal health, Development, Education, Employment and social affairs, Environment, Fisheries and aquaculture, Food safety, Information Society, Livestock, Medical profession, Public health, Science, Youth. IVSA focuses on these areas by raising awareness for problems in those fields and writing policy papers and position statements. Thereby IVSA is member of the Animal Health Advisory Committee (the working group of the Advisory Group on the food chain and animal and plant health) and will give input on related subjects when asked for. At last, IVSA works on diverse long and short term projects in the above mentioned areas, with the leadership of our standing committees and with help of our local and national Member Organizations (MOs).

column5: European Forum on Nature Conservation and Pastoralism (EFNCP)
column23:
We work to: 
     
•    Reverse the decline of the low-intensity farming types with the highest natural capital across Europe, summarised in the term High Nature Value (HNV) farming. 
•    Make these farming types socially, economically and environmentally sustainable at the farm and landscape scales in order to conserve European biodiversity and wider ecosystem services. 
•    Improve understanding, through studies and local projects, of the policy, socio-economic and cultural interactions that are key factors in the creation of a sustainable future for HNV farming. 
•    Develop, test and promote innovative policy solutions through case-studies and dialogue with local and EU partners. 
•    Enable networking and dialogue, especially between actors from the environmental and farming worlds who traditionally have not found common ground. 
•    Engage with EU policy processes, especially on the Biodiversity Strategy and CAP, and improve implementation and integration of these at national and regional levels.

column23:
The Schuman Society in Finland, founded in 2001, focuses on raising awareness of topical issues about Finland and European integration and Europe. The Society organises seminars, public debates and other events related to these issues, often in cooperation with other organisations such as the Commission Mission and EU Parliament Information Office in Finland, Europe Direct Varsinais-Suomi, EURES Varsinais-Suomi, the Europe Information network of the Finnish Ministry for Foreign Affairs, academic and research institutions, educational institutions, community partners, political parties and student organisations, as well as the Embassies and Honororay Consulates of the EU Member States.  
The Society has also produced in its publication series Finnish‐language publications such as "Kun Suomi kääntyi", "Rooman sopimus 50 vuotta", "Lissabonin sopimus tunnissa", "Eurooppa-ajattelu - suuntaviivoja tulevaisuuteen" and "Eurooppa-Akatemia ja Eurooppa-Insituutti". Its popular publication project is a pamphlet bookelt on EU and its effects to European citizens called "EU ja käyrät kurkut - Tosiasioita urbaanilegendojen sijaan" (EU and curved cucumbers - true stories instead of urban legends) with illustration and texts edited jointly with Judge Allan Rosas of EU Court. This publication has been continuously updated and published already in 5 updated editions in 2015 -2017 in printed book and ebook, and it will be developed in multilingual application . 
The Society started in 2017 its new Schuman Paper -series (in English) and revised its home pages, which now include e.g. comments and blogs. The activities are continuously developed with help of various EU and other funding opportunities and with enhanced pariticipation in Civil Society Dialogue. 
The Society has since 2013 organized EU-related debates and programs at Turku International Book and Science Fair, where it has also participated with its own stand or as part of joint "European stand" together with regional Europe Direct and EURES representatives since 2013.
